help of concept vectors, we propose a method for locating significant neurons
that are responsible for representing certain concepts and term those neurons
as concept neurons. If the number of neurons is n and the number of examples is
m, we reduce the number of forward passes required from O(n*m) to just O(n)
compared to the previous works and hence optimizing the time and computation
required over previous works. We also compare our method with several baselines
and previous methods and our results demonstrate better performance than most
of the methods and are more optimal when compared to the state-of-the-art
method. We, as part of our ablation studies, also try to optimize the search
for the concept neurons by involving clustering methods. Finally, we apply our
methods to find, turn off the neurons that we find, and analyze its
implications in parts of hate speech and bias in LLMs, and we also evaluate our
bias part in terms of Indian context. Our methodology, analysis and
explanations facilitate understating of neuron-level responsibility for more
broader and human-like concepts and also lay a path for future research in this
direction of finding concept neurons and intervening them.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a method for locating significant neurons, termed 'concept neurons', responsible for specific concepts in large language models, optimizing the computational efficiency and enhancing understanding of model behavior.
AI.motivation: Understanding the mechanisms behind predictions in large language models by identifying neurons that represent specific concepts.
AI.method: The proposed method uses concept vectors to reduce the number of forward passes from O(n*m) to O(n) for locating significant neurons, leveraging clustering methods for enhanced efficiency.
AI.result: The method demonstrates better performance than many existing methods and significantly optimizes computation compared to state-of-the-art techniques, specifically in addressing bias in language models.
AI.conclusion: The findings provide insight into neuron-level responsibilities for broader concepts and suggest avenues for future research in identifying and intervening on concept neurons.
key_contributions: Introduction of 'concept neurons' for better understanding of model predictions
Significant reduction in forward pass computations using concept vectors
Application of the methodology to analyze bias and hate speech in LLMs, particularly in an Indian context
AI.limitations: Further optimizations are still possible, and the study primarily focuses on specific bias aspects in the Indian context which may limit generalizability.

title: DeepMEL: A Multi-Agent Collaboration Framework for Multimodal Entity Linking
summary:
Multimodal Entity Linking (MEL) aims to associate textual and visual mentions
with entities in a multimodal knowledge graph. Despite its importance, current
methods face challenges such as incomplete contextual information, coarse
cross-modal fusion, and the difficulty of jointly large language models (LLMs)
and large visual models (LVMs). To address these issues, we propose DeepMEL, a
novel framework based on multi-agent collaborative reasoning, which achieves
efficient alignment and disambiguation of textual and visual modalities through
a role-specialized division strategy. DeepMEL integrates four specialized
agents, namely Modal-Fuser, Candidate-Adapter, Entity-Clozer and
Role-Orchestrator, to complete end-to-end cross-modal linking through
specialized roles and dynamic coordination. DeepMEL adopts a dual-modal
alignment path, and combines the fine-grained text semantics generated by the
LLM with the structured image representation extracted by the LVM,
significantly narrowing the modal gap. We design an adaptive iteration
strategy, combines tool-based retrieval and semantic reasoning capabilities to
dynamically optimize the candidate set and balance recall and precision.
DeepMEL also unifies MEL tasks into a structured cloze prompt to reduce parsing
complexity and enhance semantic comprehension. Extensive experiments on five
public benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepMEL achieves state-of-the-art
performance, improving ACC by 1%-57%. Ablation studies verify the effectiveness
of all modules.

AI.tldr: DeepMEL is a proposed framework for Multimodal Entity Linking, achieving efficient text-visual alignment using collaborative reasoning.
AI.motivation: Current methods in Multimodal Entity Linking struggle with contextual information and integration of language and visual models.
AI.method: DeepMEL utilizes four specialized agents for role-based tasks and a dual-modal alignment path, combining LLM-generated text semantics and LVM-derived image representations.
AI.result: DeepMEL shows significant performance improvements on five datasets, with accuracy gains ranging from 1% to 57%.
AI.conclusion: The framework is effective in aligning textual and visual modalities, thereby addressing the challenges in multimodal entity linking.
key_contributions: Introduction of a role-specialized multi-agent collaborative reasoning framework for MEL
Adaptive iteration strategy for dynamic candidate optimization
Unification of MEL tasks into a structured cloze prompt for improved semantic comprehension.

title: Annif at the GermEval-2025 LLMs4Subjects Task: Traditional XMTC Augmented by Efficient LLMs
comment:
5 pages, 4 figures, accepted at KONVENS 2025. arXiv admin note:
  substantial text overlap with arXiv:2504.19675
summary:
This paper presents the Annif system in the LLMs4Subjects shared task
(Subtask 2) at GermEval-2025. The task required creating subject predictions
for bibliographic records using large language models, with a special focus on
computational efficiency. Our system, based on the Annif automated subject
indexing toolkit, refines our previous system from the first LLMs4Subjects
shared task, which produced excellent results. We further improved the system
by using many small and efficient language models for translation and synthetic
data generation and by using LLMs for ranking candidate subjects. Our system
ranked 1st in the overall quantitative evaluation of and 1st in the qualitative
evaluation of Subtask 2.

AI.tldr: The Annif system excels in subject predictions for bibliographic records using large language models, achieving first place in both quantitative and qualitative evaluations at GermEval-2025.
AI.motivation: To create subject predictions for bibliographic records efficiently using large language models.
AI.method: The system utilizes the Annif automated subject indexing toolkit, incorporating small efficient language models for translation and synthetic data generation, alongside LLMs for ranking candidate subjects.
AI.result: The system ranked 1st in both overall quantitative evaluation and qualitative evaluation of Subtask 2 at GermEval-2025.
AI.conclusion: The enhancements made to the Annif system led to superior performance in the task of subject prediction using LLMs.
key_contributions: Refined the Annif system for improved computational efficiency.
Utilized small language models for translation and synthetic data generation.
Achieved top rankings in quantitative and qualitative evaluations at GermEval-2025.
AI.limitations: Substantial text overlap with previous work.

title: Jet-Nemotron: Efficient Language Model with Post Neural Architecture Search
summary:
We present Jet-Nemotron, a new family of hybrid-architecture language models,
which matches or exceeds the accuracy of leading full-attention models while
significantly improving generation throughput. Jet-Nemotron is developed using
Post Neural Architecture Search (PostNAS), a novel neural architecture
exploration pipeline that enables efficient model design. Unlike prior
approaches, PostNAS begins with a pre-trained full-attention model and freezes
its MLP weights, allowing efficient exploration of attention block designs. The
pipeline includes four key components: (1) learning optimal full-attention
layer placement and elimination, (2) linear attention block selection, (3)
designing new attention blocks, and (4) performing hardware-aware
hyperparameter search. Our Jet-Nemotron-2B model achieves comparable or
superior accuracy to Qwen3, Qwen2.5, Gemma3, and Llama3.2 across a
comprehensive suite of benchmarks while delivering up to 53.6x generation
throughput speedup and 6.1x prefilling speedup. It also achieves higher
accuracy on MMLU and MMLU-Pro than recent advanced MoE full-attention models,
such as DeepSeek-V3-Small and Moonlight, despite their larger scale with 15B
total and 2.2B activated parameters.

AI.tldr: Jet-Nemotron introduces a hybrid-architecture language model that outperforms traditional full-attention models in accuracy and generation speed.
AI.motivation: To enhance language model performance and generation throughput while maintaining or exceeding accuracy compared to existing models.
AI.method: Jet-Nemotron utilizes Post Neural Architecture Search (PostNAS) to explore model designs; this includes strategies for optimal layer placement, linear attention block selection, and hardware-aware hyperparameter search.
AI.result: The Jet-Nemotron-2B model achieves superior accuracy and vastly improved generation speed, surpassing various notable models like Qwen3 and Llama3.2 across multiple benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Jet-Nemotron demonstrates that hybrid architectures can significantly enhance performance metrics in language modeling while maintaining efficiency in execution.
key_contributions: Introduction of Jet-Nemotron as a new hybrid-architecture language model
Development of PostNAS for efficient architecture exploration
Achieves comparable or superior performance to larger models with higher throughput.

title: Evaluating Structured Decoding for Text-to-Table Generation: Evidence from Three Datasets
comment:
to be published in the workshop proceedings of the "From Rules to
  Language Models: Comparative Performance Evaluation" workshop, held alongside
  RANLP 2025
summary:
We present a comprehensive evaluation of structured decoding for
text-to-table generation with large language models (LLMs). While previous work
has primarily focused on unconstrained generation of tables, the impact of
enforcing structural constraints during generation remains underexplored. We
systematically compare schema-guided (structured) decoding to standard one-shot
prompting across three diverse benchmarks - E2E, Rotowire, and Livesum - using
open-source LLMs of up to 32B parameters, assessing the performance of table
generation approaches in resource-constrained settings. Our experiments cover a
wide range of evaluation metrics at cell, row, and table levels. Results
demonstrate that structured decoding significantly enhances the validity and
alignment of generated tables, particularly in scenarios demanding precise
numerical alignment (Rotowire), but may degrade performance in contexts
involving densely packed textual information (E2E) or extensive aggregation
over lengthy texts (Livesum). We further analyze the suitability of different
evaluation metrics and discuss the influence of model size.

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates the effectiveness of structured decoding for text-to-table generation with large language models, highlighting its advantages and limitations across various benchmarks.
AI.motivation: The study addresses the underexplored impact of enforcing structural constraints in table generation by large language models, aiming to improve evaluation methodologies in resource-constrained settings.
AI.method: The authors systematically compare schema-guided (structured) decoding to standard one-shot prompting using diverse benchmarks and open-source LLMs, focusing on a variety of evaluation metrics.
AI.result: Structured decoding significantly improves the validity and alignment of generated tables, especially in scenarios requiring precise numerical alignment, while showing potential drawbacks in contexts with dense text or extensive aggregation.
AI.conclusion: While structured decoding offers notable benefits, its effectiveness varies based on the type of data being processed and the evaluation metrics used, suggesting the need for careful consideration in implementation.
key_contributions: Systematic evaluation of structured decoding against one-shot prompting.
Insights into the performance of table generation in resource-constrained settings.
Analysis of evaluation metrics and model size influence on performance.
AI.limitations: Structured decoding may hinder performance in scenarios with dense text or lengthy aggregations.

title: Dancing with Deer: A Constructional Perspective on MWEs in the Era of LLMs
comment:
Chapter in Phraseology and Multiword Expressions, Language Science
  Press (to appear)
summary:
In this chapter, we argue for the benefits of understanding multiword
expressions from the perspective of usage-based, construction grammar
approaches. We begin with a historical overview of how construction grammar was
developed in order to account for idiomatic expressions using the same
grammatical machinery as the non-idiomatic structures of language. We cover a
comprehensive description of constructions, which are pairings of meaning with
form of any size (morpheme, word, phrase), as well as how constructional
approaches treat the acquisition and generalization of constructions. We
describe a successful case study leveraging constructional templates for
representing multiword expressions in English PropBank. Because constructions
can be at any level or unit of form, we then illustrate the benefit of a
constructional representation of multi-meaningful morphosyntactic unit
constructions in Arapaho, a highly polysynthetic and agglutinating language. We
include a second case study leveraging constructional templates for
representing these multi-morphemic expressions in Uniform Meaning
Representation. Finally, we demonstrate the similarities and differences
between a usage-based explanation of a speaker learning a novel multiword
expression, such as "dancing with deer," and that of a large language model. We
present experiments showing that both models and speakers can generalize the
meaning of novel multiword expressions based on a single exposure of usage.
However, only speakers can reason over the combination of two such expressions,
as this requires comparison of the novel forms to a speaker's lifetime of
stored constructional exemplars, which are rich with cross-modal details.

AI.tldr: This chapter discusses the advantages of usage-based construction grammar for understanding multiword expressions, supported by historical context, case studies, and comparisons with language models.
AI.motivation: To explore the benefits of usage-based construction grammar in analyzing multiword expressions and how it can enhance understanding of linguistic structures.
AI.method: The chapter reviews the development of construction grammar, presents case studies on multiword expression representations, and compares human learning processes with large language models.
AI.result: Successful use of constructional templates for English PropBank and Uniform Meaning Representation; demonstrating similarities in generalization capabilities between speakers and models.
AI.conclusion: Human speakers can reason with multiple expressions through stored constructional examples, unlike language models, which highlights the complexities of human language acquisition.
key_contributions: Historical overview of construction grammar
Case studies illustrating multiword expression representations
Comparative analysis between human and model learning of multiword expressions

title: Political Ideology Shifts in Large Language Models
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed in politically
sensitive settings, raising concerns about their potential to encode, amplify,
or be steered toward specific ideologies. We investigate how adopting synthetic
personas influences ideological expression in LLMs across seven models (7B-70B+
parameters) from multiple families, using the Political Compass Test as a
standardized probe. Our analysis reveals four consistent patterns: (i) larger
models display broader and more polarized implicit ideological coverage; (ii)
susceptibility to explicit ideological cues grows with scale; (iii) models
respond more strongly to right-authoritarian than to left-libertarian priming;
and (iv) thematic content in persona descriptions induces systematic and
predictable ideological shifts, which amplify with size. These findings
indicate that both scale and persona content shape LLM political behavior. As
such systems enter decision-making, educational, and policy contexts, their
latent ideological malleability demands attention to safeguard fairness,
transparency, and safety.

AI.tldr: This paper explores the impact of synthetic personas on the ideological expression of large language models (LLMs), revealing how model size and persona content affect their political behavior.
AI.motivation: The research investigates the role of LLMs in politically sensitive contexts and aims to understand how they can encode and amplify specific ideologies.
AI.method: The study uses the Political Compass Test to probe ideological expression in seven LLMs, ranging from 7B to 70B+ parameters, analyzing consistent patterns of ideological coverage and response to persona descriptions.
AI.result: Findings show that larger models exhibit broader ideological coverage, increased susceptibility to explicit cues, stronger responses to right-authoritarian priming, and predictable shifts in ideology based on persona content, particularly amplifying with model size.
AI.conclusion: These insights underscore the need for attention to the ideological implications of LLMs as they are adopted in sensitive decision-making contexts, advocating for measures to ensure fairness and transparency.
key_contributions: Identified consistent patterns of ideological expression in LLMs based on size and persona content.
Demonstrated that larger models are more susceptible to ideological biases in stimuli.
Highlighted the risks of ideological malleability in LLMs in sensitive applications.

title: X-Troll: eXplainable Detection of State-Sponsored Information Operations Agents
comment: 14 pages, 4 figures, 4 tables, accepted by CIKM2025
summary:
State-sponsored trolls, malicious actors who deploy sophisticated linguistic
manipulation in coordinated information campaigns, posing threats to online
discourse integrity. While Large Language Models (LLMs) achieve strong
performance on general natural language processing (NLP) tasks, they struggle
with subtle propaganda detection and operate as ``black boxes'', providing no
interpretable insights into manipulation strategies. This paper introduces
X-Troll, a novel framework that bridges this gap by integrating explainable
adapter-based LLMs with expert-derived linguistic knowledge to detect
state-sponsored trolls and provide human-readable explanations for its
decisions. X-Troll incorporates appraisal theory and propaganda analysis
through specialized LoRA adapters, using dynamic gating to capture
campaign-specific discourse patterns in coordinated information operations.
Experiments on real-world data demonstrate that our linguistically-informed
approach shows strong performance compared with both general LLM baselines and
existing troll detection models in accuracy while providing enhanced
transparency through expert-grounded explanations that reveal the specific
linguistic strategies used by state-sponsored actors. X-Troll source code is
available at: https://github.com/ltian678/xtroll_source/.

AI.tldr: X-Troll is a framework for detecting state-sponsored trolls using explainable AI in LLMs, providing insights into manipulation strategies.
AI.motivation: To address the inadequacies of LLMs in detecting subtle propaganda and to enhance transparency in automated decision-making processes.
AI.method: X-Troll integrates explainable adapter-based LLMs with linguistic knowledge through specialized LoRA adapters, employing appraisal theory and dynamic gating for analyzing discourse patterns.
AI.result: Experiments reveal that X-Troll outperforms general LLMs and existing troll detection models in accuracy while offering clear explanations of the linguistic strategies employed by trolls.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework not only improves detection accuracy but also enhances understanding of manipulation tactics, making it a valuable tool for maintaining online discourse integrity.
key_contributions: Introduction of X-Troll framework for troll detection
Integration of explainable AI with linguistic knowledge
Demonstrated superior performance and interpretability compared to existing models.

title: OpenWHO: A Document-Level Parallel Corpus for Health Translation in Low-Resource Languages
summary:
In machine translation (MT), health is a high-stakes domain characterised by
widespread deployment and domain-specific vocabulary. However, there is a lack
of MT evaluation datasets for low-resource languages in this domain. To address
this gap, we introduce OpenWHO, a document-level parallel corpus of 2,978
documents and 26,824 sentences from the World Health Organization's e-learning
platform. Sourced from expert-authored, professionally translated materials
shielded from web-crawling, OpenWHO spans a diverse range of over 20 languages,
of which nine are low-resource. Leveraging this new resource, we evaluate
modern large language models (LLMs) against traditional MT models. Our findings
reveal that LLMs consistently outperform traditional MT models, with Gemini 2.5
Flash achieving a +4.79 ChrF point improvement over NLLB-54B on our
low-resource test set. Further, we investigate how LLM context utilisation
affects accuracy, finding that the benefits of document-level translation are
most pronounced in specialised domains like health. We release the OpenWHO
corpus to encourage further research into low-resource MT in the health domain.

AI.tldr: OpenWHO is a new parallel corpus for machine translation in health, focusing on low-resource languages, demonstrating LLMs' superiority over traditional MT models.
AI.motivation: To address the lack of evaluation datasets for machine translation in the health domain, particularly for low-resource languages.
AI.method: Introduction of the OpenWHO document-level parallel corpus comprising 2,978 documents and 26,824 sentences, alongside comparisons of LLMs to traditional MT models.
AI.result: LLMs, particularly Gemini 2.5 Flash, performed significantly better than traditional MT models on a low-resource test set.
AI.conclusion: The OpenWHO corpus is aimed at advancing research in low-resource machine translation within the healthcare sector, highlighting the efficiency of document-level translation for specialized domains.
key_contributions: Launch of OpenWHO, a corpus for low-resource health translation
Demonstration of LLM superiority over traditional MT
Investigation of LLM context utilization in document-level translation.

title: Ethical Considerations of Large Language Models in Game Playing
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated tremendous potential in game
playing, while little attention has been paid to their ethical implications in
those contexts. This work investigates and analyses the ethical considerations
of applying LLMs in game playing, using Werewolf, also known as Mafia, as a
case study. Gender bias, which affects game fairness and player experience, has
been observed from the behaviour of LLMs. Some roles, such as the Guard and
Werewolf, are more sensitive than others to gender information, presented as a
higher degree of behavioural change. We further examine scenarios in which
gender information is implicitly conveyed through names, revealing that LLMs
still exhibit discriminatory tendencies even in the absence of explicit gender
labels. This research showcases the importance of developing fair and ethical
LLMs. Beyond our research findings, we discuss the challenges and opportunities
that lie ahead in this field, emphasising the need for diving deeper into the
ethical implications of LLMs in gaming and other interactive domains.

AI.tldr: This paper examines the ethical implications of using large language models (LLMs) in game playing, focusing on gender bias in the game Werewolf.
AI.motivation: To analyze the ethical considerations of applying LLMs in gaming contexts, particularly their impact on fairness and player experience.
AI.method: Case study analysis of LLM behavior in the game Werewolf, evaluating the influence of gender bias on gameplay and outcomes.
AI.result: Identified that LLMs exhibit gender bias, affecting roles such as Guard and Werewolf, and showing discriminatory tendencies even without explicit gender labels.
AI.conclusion: The study highlights the need for ethical development of LLMs and calls for further research into their implications in gaming and interactive domains.
key_contributions: Analysis of gender bias in LLMs within game contexts
Identification of the effects of implicit gender information on gameplay
Discussion of ethical challenges and opportunities in LLMs for gaming
AI.limitations: Focused specifically on gender bias; other ethical considerations in LLMs may not be addressed.

title: Less Redundancy: Boosting Practicality of Vision Language Model in Walking Assistants
summary:
Approximately 283 million people worldwide live with visual impairments,
motivating increasing research into leveraging Visual Language Models (VLMs) to
develop effective walking assistance systems for blind and low vision
individuals. However, existing VLMs in walking assistant task often have
outputs that contain considerable redundancy and extraneous details, adversely
affecting users' ability to accurately assess their surroundings. Moreover,
these models typically lack the capability to proactively assess environmental
risks and adaptively trigger reminders based on the appropriate scene, leading
to excessive temporal redundancy. To mitigate output and temporal redundancy,
we propose WalkVLM-LR, a walking assistance model with less redundancy. To
reduce output redundancy, we introduce four human-preference-based custom
reward functions within the GRPO-based reasoning framework to optimize the
output in terms of conciseness, fluency, keyword density, and accuracy, thereby
producing more informative and streamlined outputs. To minimize temporal
redundancy, we incorporate an environment awareness discriminator, which shares
the visual encoder with the VLMs to reduce redundant computations and enhance
discriminative efficiency, to make WalkVLM-LR assess scene risk levels and
minimize unnecessary reminders. Experimental results demonstrate that our
method achieves state-of-the-art performance across all evaluation metrics
compared with other models, particularly in output conciseness and less
temporal redundancy.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes WalkVLM-LR, a walking assistance model for visually impaired users that minimizes output and temporal redundancy by leveraging human-preference-based custom reward functions and an environment awareness discriminator.
AI.motivation: Around 283 million people are visually impaired, necessitating effective walking assistance systems that can provide accurate and concise information about their surroundings.
AI.method: WalkVLM-LR is developed using four custom reward functions within a GRPO-based reasoning framework to optimize output conciseness, fluency, keyword density, and accuracy. An environment awareness discriminator helps assess scene risk levels and reduce redundant reminders.
AI.result: WalkVLM-LR achieves state-of-the-art performance in output conciseness and temporal redundancy across all evaluation metrics compared to existing models.
AI.conclusion: The proposed model not only enhances information quality but also minimizes unnecessary computational load and improves user experience for the visually impaired.
key_contributions: Introduction of WalkVLM-LR model with less redundancy for walking assistance.
Application of human-preference-based custom reward functions to improve output.
Development of an environment awareness discriminator to reduce computational redundancy.

title: CEQuest: Benchmarking Large Language Models for Construction Estimation
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities across
a wide range of general-domain tasks. However, their effectiveness in
specialized fields, such as construction, remains underexplored. In this paper,
we introduce CEQuest, a novel benchmark dataset specifically designed to
evaluate the performance of LLMs in answering construction-related questions,
particularly in the areas of construction drawing interpretation and
estimation. We conduct comprehensive experiments using five state-of-the-art
LLMs, including Gemma 3, Phi4, LLaVA, Llama 3.3, and GPT-4.1, and evaluate
their performance in terms of accuracy, execution time, and model size. Our
experimental results demonstrate that current LLMs exhibit considerable room
for improvement, highlighting the importance of integrating domain-specific
knowledge into these models. To facilitate further research, we will
open-source the proposed CEQuest dataset, aiming to foster the development of
specialized large language models (LLMs) tailored to the construction domain.

AI.tldr: Introduction of CEQuest, a benchmark dataset for evaluating LLMs in construction-related tasks.
AI.motivation: To assess the performance of LLMs in specialized fields like construction, which has been underexplored.
AI.method: Comprehensive experiments were conducted using five state-of-the-art LLMs (Gemma 3, Phi4, LLaVA, Llama 3.3, GPT-4.1) to evaluate their performance on construction drawing interpretation and estimation tasks.
AI.result: Current LLMs show significant room for improvement in accuracy and efficiency for construction-related queries.
AI.conclusion: The study emphasizes the need for integrating domain-specific knowledge into LLMs and will open-source the CEQuest dataset to promote development in this area.
key_contributions: Introduction of CEQuest, a specialized benchmark dataset for construction tasks
Evaluation of multiple state-of-the-art LLMs in a specialized field
Highlighting the need for domain-specific knowledge integration in LLMs
AI.limitations: The dataset is specific to construction and may not generalize to other fields.

title: CYCLE-INSTRUCT: Fully Seed-Free Instruction Tuning via Dual Self-Training and Cycle Consistency
summary:
Instruction tuning is vital for aligning large language models (LLMs) with
human intent, but current methods typically rely on costly human-annotated seed
data or powerful external teacher models. While instruction back-translation
techniques reduce this dependency, they remain fundamentally tethered to an
initial seed set, which limits full automation, introduces biases, and can lead
to inefficient use of unlabeled corpora. In this paper, we propose
Cycle-Instruct, a novel framework that achieves fully seed-free instruction
tuning. Inspired by cycle consistency, Cycle-Instruct employs a dual
self-training loop where two models-an answer generator and a question
generator-are bootstrapped solely from raw, unlabeled text. These models
mutually supervise each other by reconstructing original text segments from
their counterpart's generated pseudo-labels, effectively learning from the
intrinsic structure of the data without any human-provided seeds. We
demonstrate Cycle-Instruct's efficacy across four diverse data tracks,
including general instruction-following, domain-specific tasks, dialogue logs,
and plain text. Our extensive experiments show that Cycle-Instruct not only
outperforms seed-driven back-translation baselines but also achieves
performance comparable to strongly supervised methods.

AI.tldr: Cycle-Instruct is a novel framework for seed-free instruction tuning of large language models, utilizing a dual self-training loop to enhance model alignment without human-annotated data.
AI.motivation: The need for fully automated and unbiased instruction tuning of large language models without relying on costly human-annotated seed data or external teacher models.
AI.method: Cycle-Instruct uses a dual self-training loop involving an answer generator and a question generator that mutually supervise each other using raw unlabeled text.
AI.result: Cycle-Instruct outperforms traditional seed-driven back-translation methods and achieves performance on par with strongly supervised approaches across four diverse data tracks.
AI.conclusion: The Cycle-Instruct framework provides a promising solution to achieving efficient and unbiased instruction tuning of LLMs without human input.
key_contributions: Introduces a seed-free instruction tuning framework
Employs dual self-training for mutual supervision
Demonstrates superior performance across various tasks compared to seed-driven methods

title: From Indirect Object Identification to Syllogisms: Exploring Binary Mechanisms in Transformer Circuits
summary:
Transformer-based language models (LMs) can perform a wide range of tasks,
and mechanistic interpretability (MI) aims to reverse engineer the components
responsible for task completion to understand their behavior. Previous MI
research has focused on linguistic tasks such as Indirect Object Identification
(IOI). In this paper, we investigate the ability of GPT-2 small to handle
binary truth values by analyzing its behavior with syllogistic prompts, e.g.,
"Statement A is true. Statement B matches statement A. Statement B is", which
requires more complex logical reasoning compared to IOI. Through our analysis
of several syllogism tasks of varying difficulty, we identify multiple circuits
that mechanistically explain GPT-2's logical-reasoning capabilities and uncover
binary mechanisms that facilitate task completion, including the ability to
produce a negated token not present in the input prompt through negative heads.
Our evaluation using a faithfulness metric shows that a circuit comprising five
attention heads achieves over 90% of the original model's performance. By
relating our findings to IOI analysis, we provide new insights into the roles
of specific attention heads and MLPs in LMs. These insights contribute to a
broader understanding of model reasoning and support future research in
mechanistic interpretability.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates GPT-2's logical reasoning capabilities by analyzing its behavior with syllogistic prompts and identifies circuits that explain its performance in handling binary truth values.
AI.motivation: To understand the behavior of transformer-based language models through mechanistic interpretability, specifically focusing on their logical reasoning capabilities.
AI.method: Analyzing GPT-2 small's responses to syllogistic prompts and evaluating its circuits involved in processing logical reasoning tasks of varying difficulty.
AI.result: Identified multiple circuits in GPT-2 that explain its logical-reasoning skills and discovered mechanisms facilitating task completion, including circuits that produce negated tokens.
AI.conclusion: Provided new insights into the roles of attention heads and MLPs in language models, contributing to the understanding of model reasoning and future mechanistic interpretability research.
key_contributions: Identified circuits that enable logical reasoning in GPT-2.
Developed a faithfulness metric showing high performance retention with specific attention circuits.
Provided insights that bridge previous IOI analysis and new syllogistic task approaches.

title: Text Takes Over: A Study of Modality Bias in Multimodal Intent Detection
summary:
The rise of multimodal data, integrating text, audio, and visuals, has
created new opportunities for studying multimodal tasks such as intent
detection. This work investigates the effectiveness of Large Language Models
(LLMs) and non-LLMs, including text-only and multi-modal models, in the
multimodal intent detection task. Our study reveals that Mistral-7B, a
text-only LLM, outperforms most competitive multimodal models by approximately
9% on MIntRec-1 and 4% on MIntRec2.0 datasets. This performance advantage comes
from a strong textual bias in these datasets, where over 90% of the samples
require textual input, either alone or in combination with other modalities,
for correct classification. We confirm the modality bias of these datasets via
human evaluation, too. Next, we propose a framework to debias the datasets, and
upon debiasing, more than 70% of the samples in MIntRec-1 and more than 50% in
MIntRec2.0 get removed, resulting in significant performance degradation across
all models, with smaller multimodal fusion models being the most affected with
an accuracy drop of over 50 - 60%. Further, we analyze the context-specific
relevance of different modalities through empirical analysis. Our findings
highlight the challenges posed by modality bias in multimodal intent datasets
and emphasize the need for unbiased datasets to evaluate multimodal models
effectively.

AI.tldr: This study examines the performance of Large Language Models (LLMs) and multimodal models in intent detection, showing text-only models can outperform multimodal ones due to dataset biases toward textual input. It also addresses modality bias and proposes a debiasing framework.
AI.motivation: To explore the effectiveness of LLMs and non-LLMs in multimodal intent detection, given the rise of multimodal data.
AI.method: Investigated the performance of Mistral-7B and other models on MIntRec-1 and MIntRec2.0 datasets, confirming modality bias via human evaluation and proposed a framework for dataset debiasing.
AI.result: Mistral-7B outperforms multimodal models by 9% on MIntRec-1 and 4% on MIntRec2.0. Debiasing the datasets leads to the removal of over 70% of samples, significantly reducing model performance.
AI.conclusion: The study highlights the challenges of modality bias in multimodal datasets and the necessity for unbiased datasets to effectively evaluate multimodal models.
key_contributions: Demonstrated that text-only LLMs can outperform multimodal models in intent detection tasks.
Proposed a framework to debias multimodal datasets, revealing performance implications on model accuracy.
Confirmed modality bias in datasets through empirical analysis and human evaluation.
AI.limitations: The findings depend on the specific datasets used, which may not generalize to all multimodal tasks.

title: XLQA: A Benchmark for Locale-Aware Multilingual Open-Domain Question Answering
comment:
Accepted to EMNLP 2025 main conference. 12 pages, 4 figures, 7
  tables. Code is available at https://github.com/ro-ko/XLQA
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown significant progress in Open-domain
question answering (ODQA), yet most evaluations focus on English and assume
locale-invariant answers across languages. This assumption neglects the
cultural and regional variations that affect question understanding and answer,
leading to biased evaluation in multilingual benchmarks. To address these
limitations, we introduce XLQA, a novel benchmark explicitly designed for
locale-sensitive multilingual ODQA. XLQA contains 3,000 English seed questions
expanded to eight languages, with careful filtering for semantic consistency
and human-verified annotations distinguishing locale-invariant and
locale-sensitive cases. Our evaluation of five state-of-the-art multilingual
LLMs reveals notable failures on locale-sensitive questions, exposing gaps
between English and other languages due to a lack of locale-grounding
knowledge. We provide a systematic framework and scalable methodology for
assessing multilingual QA under diverse cultural contexts, offering a critical
resource to advance the real-world applicability of multilingual ODQA systems.
Our findings suggest that disparities in training data distribution contribute
to differences in both linguistic competence and locale-awareness across
models.

AI.tldr: XLQA introduces a benchmark for locale-sensitive multilingual open-domain question answering, revealing significant gaps in multilingual LLM performance.
AI.motivation: Current evaluations in open-domain question answering often ignore cultural and regional variations, leading to biased results in multilingual benchmarks.
AI.method: XLQA consists of 3,000 English seed questions transformed into eight languages, with annotations distinguishing locale-invariant and locale-sensitive queries, paired with evaluations of multilingual LLMs.
AI.result: Evaluation of five state-of-the-art multilingual LLMs showed notable failures on locale-sensitive questions, revealing gaps in knowledge due to lack of locale-grounding.
AI.conclusion: XLQA provides a critical resource for improving real-world multilingual QA systems by addressing cultural context disparities.
key_contributions: Introduction of a benchmark for locale-sensitive multilingual ODQA
Systematic framework for evaluating multilingual QA
Highlighting locality-related gaps in LLMs' knowledge
AI.limitations: The benchmark may not encompass all cultural variations; its impact relies on the adoption by the community.

title: ParamBench: A Graduate-Level Benchmark for Evaluating LLM Understanding on Indic Subjects
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have been widely evaluated on tasks such as
comprehension, question answering, summarization, code generation, etc.
However, their performance on graduate-level, culturally grounded questions in
the Indian context remains largely unexplored. Existing Indian benchmarks
emphasise basic fact-orientated queries that offer limited assessment of a
deeper disciplinary understanding tailored to the Indian setting. In this
paper, we present ParamBench, consisting of around 11.5K questions in Hindi
language comprising questionnaires from 16 diverse subjects. These questions
are primarily derived from nation-wide graduate level entrance examination
covering topics such as history, music, instruments, yoga, literature,
philosophy, law, etc., specifically for the Indian context. Additionally, we
assess the ability of LLMs to handle diverse question formats-such as
list-based matching, assertion-reason pairs, and sequence ordering-alongside
conventional multiple-choice questions. We evaluated the performance of more
than 17 open source LLMs on this benchmark, observing that Llama 3.3 70B
attains the highest overall accuracy of 48%. Furthermore, subject-wise analysis
indicates that even for the best performing LLMs, performance remains weak on
topics such as music, classical instruments, politics and archaeology,
underscoring persistent challenges in culturally grounded reasoning.

AI.tldr: This paper presents ParamBench, a benchmark of 11.5K culturally grounded questions in Hindi for evaluating LLMs in the Indian context, highlighting performance challenges in certain subjects.
AI.motivation: To address the lack of evaluation of large language models on graduate-level questions tailored to the Indian cultural context, which goes beyond basic fact-oriented queries.
AI.method: Introduced the ParamBench dataset consisting of 11.5K questions across 16 subjects derived from national graduate entrance examinations, and conducted performance evaluations on 17 open-source LLMs using diverse question formats.
AI.result: The highest accuracy observed was 48% by Llama 3.3 70B, with noted weaknesses in areas such as music, classical instruments, and politics.
AI.conclusion: While LLMs can perform on graduate-level questions, their effectiveness is limited in culturally specific topics, indicating a need for better grounding in diverse reasoning.
key_contributions: Introduction of the ParamBench dataset for Hindi questions in the Indian context
Evaluation of over 17 open-source LLMs on diverse question types
Insights into the performance gaps of LLMs on culturally grounded subjects
AI.limitations: The benchmark may not cover all aspects of cultural depth and reasoning, and specific weaknesses in LLM performance were noted in several subjects.

title: Seeing is Believing: Emotion-Aware Audio-Visual Language Modeling for Expressive Speech Generation
summary:
We present an Audio-Visual Language Model (AVLM) for expressive speech
generation by integrating full-face visual cues into a pre-trained expressive
speech model. We explore multiple visual encoders and multimodal fusion
strategies during pre-training to identify the most effective integration
approach. Subsequent fine-tuning on emotion recognition and expressive dialogue
tasks yields substantial gains over speech-only baselines (e.g., +5 F1 in
emotion recognition). AVLM highlights the value of expressive visual
information in guiding speech generation and offers a foundation for end-to-end
multimodal conversational systems.

AI.tldr: A multimodal model integrating visual cues for improved speech generation.
AI.motivation: To enhance expressive speech generation by incorporating full-face visual cues, addressing the limitations of speech-only models.
AI.method: Integrates multiple visual encoders and fusion strategies during pre-training with a focus on fine-tuning for emotion recognition and dialogue tasks.
AI.result: Achieves significant improvements in F1 score for emotion recognition (+5) compared to baseline models.
AI.conclusion: The AVLM demonstrates the effectiveness of visual cues in expressive speech generation and paves the way for multimodal conversational systems.
key_contributions: Introduction of Audio-Visual Language Model (AVLM) for expressive speech synthesis.
Identification of effective visual encoders and fusion strategies for multimodal learning.
Demonstrated performance improvements in emotion recognition and expressive dialogue over traditional methods.

title: ComicScene154: A Scene Dataset for Comic Analysis
summary:
Comics offer a compelling yet under-explored domain for computational
narrative analysis, combining text and imagery in ways distinct from purely
textual or audiovisual media. We introduce ComicScene154, a manually annotated
dataset of scene-level narrative arcs derived from public-domain comic books
spanning diverse genres. By conceptualizing comics as an abstraction for
narrative-driven, multimodal data, we highlight their potential to inform
broader research on multi-modal storytelling. To demonstrate the utility of
ComicScene154, we present a baseline scene segmentation pipeline, providing an
initial benchmark that future studies can build upon. Our results indicate that
ComicScene154 constitutes a valuable resource for advancing computational
methods in multimodal narrative understanding and expanding the scope of comic
analysis within the Natural Language Processing community.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces ComicScene154, a dataset for analyzing narrative arcs in comics, highlighting its potential for multimodal narrative research.
AI.motivation: To explore the under-researched domain of comics for computational narrative analysis and to advance multimodal storytelling methodologies.
AI.method: The authors created ComicScene154, a manually annotated dataset of scene-level narrative arcs from public-domain comics and established a baseline scene segmentation pipeline to benchmark future research.
AI.result: ComicScene154 has been demonstrated to be a valuable resource for narrative understanding and comic analysis in the NLP community.
AI.conclusion: The dataset offers a novel resource for advancing computational methods in the study of multimodal narratives and can inspire further research in comic analysis.
key_contributions: Introduction of ComicScene154 dataset for comics analysis
Establishment of a baseline scene segmentation pipeline
Contribution to multimodal storytelling research within NLP.

title: CMR-SPB: Cross-Modal Multi-Hop Reasoning over Text, Image, and Speech with Path Balance
summary:
Cross-modal multi-hop reasoning (CMR) is a valuable yet underexplored
capability of multimodal large language models (MLLMs), entailing the
integration of information from multiple modalities to produce a coherent
output for a given context. We argue that existing benchmarks for evaluating
this ability have critical shortcomings: (1) they largely overlook the speech
modality, and (2) they exhibit heavily biased reasoning path distributions,
which can severely undermine fair evaluation. To address these limitations, we
introduce a novel benchmark -- Cross-Modal Multi-Hop Reasoning over Text, Image
and Speech with Path Balance (CMR-SPB) -- designed to assess tri-modal
multi-hop reasoning while ensuring both unbiased and diverse reasoning paths.
Our experiments with the new dataset reveal consistent model failures in
specific reasoning sequences and show that biased benchmarks risk
misrepresenting model performance. Finally, based on our extensive analysis, we
propose a new ECV (Extract, Connect, Verify) prompting technique that
effectively mitigates the performance gap across different reasoning paths.
Overall, we call for more careful evaluation in CMR to advance the development
of robust multimodal AI.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a novel benchmark for evaluating cross-modal multi-hop reasoning in multimodal large language models, addressing shortcomings in existing methods.
AI.motivation: To improve the evaluation of cross-modal multi-hop reasoning by addressing the lack of benchmarks that include speech modalities and the biases present in existing reasoning path distributions.
AI.method: We develop a new benchmark called Cross-Modal Multi-Hop Reasoning over Text, Image and Speech with Path Balance (CMR-SPB) to evaluate tri-modal reasoning capabilities.
AI.result: Our experiments show consistent model failures in specific reasoning sequences and reveal that biased benchmarks can misrepresent model performance.
AI.conclusion: We advocate for careful evaluation methods in cross-modal reasoning to enhance the robustness of multimodal AI, presenting the ECV prompting technique to reduce performance gaps.
key_contributions: Introduction of CMR-SPB benchmark
Identification of biases in existing benchmarks
Proposal of ECV prompting technique

title: TULIP: Adapting Open-Source Large Language Models for Underrepresented Languages and Specialized Financial Tasks
summary:
Thanks to the growing popularity of large language models over the years,
there is great potential for their applications in finance. Despite the
exceptional performance of larger proprietary models, which are presented as
black-box solutions through APIs, smaller models that can be hosted on-premise
present opportunities for adaptability and privacy. Especially in cases where
the management of sensitive information and application of domain knowledge is
important, like finance, enhancing the capabilities of smaller models becomes
crucial, notably for underrepresented languages. In this work, we introduce
TULIP models, which adapt Llama 3.1 8B and Qwen 2.5 7B for domain and language
adaptation, focusing on financial Turkish use cases.
  The five-stage development pipeline involves data collection, continual
pre-training (CPT), benchmark design, synthetic data generation and supervised
fine-tuning (SFT). The results show that the capabilities of the models can be
enhanced to effectively accomplish targeted tasks in this specific domain and
language.

AI.tldr: This paper presents the TULIP models, which adapt Llama 3.1 8B and Qwen 2.5 7B for financial applications in Turkish, highlighting the importance of smaller, on-premise language models.
AI.motivation: There is significant potential for large language models in finance, but smaller, adaptable models can address privacy and domain-specific challenges, particularly for underrepresented languages.
AI.method: The development pipeline consists of five stages: data collection, continual pre-training (CPT), benchmark design, synthetic data generation, and supervised fine-tuning (SFT).
AI.result: The adapted models show enhanced capabilities for targeted financial tasks in Turkish, showcasing their effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: Enhancing smaller models for specific domains like finance is key to leveraging their capabilities while ensuring privacy and adaptability.
key_contributions: Introduction of TULIP models for financial use cases in Turkish
Framework for continual pre-training and supervised fine-tuning
Emphasis on adaptation for underrepresented languages in finance

title: M3TQA: Massively Multilingual Multitask Table Question Answering
summary:
Tabular data is a fundamental component of real-world information systems,
yet most research in table understanding remains confined to English, leaving
multilingual comprehension significantly underexplored. Existing multilingual
table benchmarks suffer from geolinguistic imbalance - overrepresenting certain
languages and lacking sufficient scale for rigorous cross-lingual analysis. To
address these limitations, we introduce a comprehensive framework for massively
multilingual multitask table question answering, featuring m3TQA-Instruct, a
large-scale benchmark spanning 97 languages across diverse language families,
including underrepresented and low-resource languages. We construct m3TQA by
curating 50 real-world tables in Chinese and English, then applying a robust
six-step LLM-based translation pipeline powered by DeepSeek and GPT-4o,
achieving high translation fidelity with a median BLEU score of 60.19 as
validated through back-translation. The benchmark includes 2,916 professionally
annotated question-answering pairs across four tasks designed to evaluate
nuanced table reasoning capabilities. Experiments on state-of-the-art LLMs
reveal critical insights into cross-lingual generalization, demonstrating that
synthetically generated, unannotated QA data can significantly boost
performance, particularly for low-resource languages. M3T-Bench establishes a
new standard for multilingual table understanding, providing both a challenging
evaluation platform and a scalable methodology for future research.

AI.tldr: Introduction of a new multilingual benchmark for table question answering across 97 languages.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of existing multilingual table understanding research, specifically the geolinguistic imbalance and insufficient scale for rigorous analysis.
AI.method: A comprehensive framework called m3TQA-Instruct is developed, which includes a robust six-step LLM-based translation pipeline with DeepSeek and GPT-4o to create a new benchmark with 2,916 annotated question-answering pairs.
AI.result: Experiments indicate that unannotated QA data can enhance performance particularly for low-resource languages, establishing a new benchmark for multilingual table comprehension.
AI.conclusion: M3T-Bench provides a challenging new evaluation platform and methodology for multilingual table understanding research.
key_contributions: Creation of m3TQA, a benchmark spanning 97 languages
Introduction of a high-fidelity LLM-based translation pipeline
Demonstration of improved performance in low-resource languages with synthetic data

title: From Confidence to Collapse in LLM Factual Robustness
summary:
Ensuring the robustness of factual knowledge in LLMs is critical for reliable
applications in tasks such as question answering and reasoning. However,
existing evaluation methods predominantly focus on performance-based metrics,
often investigating from the perspective of prompt perturbations, which
captures only the externally triggered side of knowledge robustness. To bridge
this gap, we introduce a principled approach to measure factual robustness from
the perspective of the generation process by analyzing token distribution
entropy in combination with temperature scaling sensitivity. These two factors
build the Factual Robustness Score (FRS), a novel metric which quantifies the
stability of a fact against perturbations in decoding conditions, given its
initial uncertainty. To validate our approach, we conduct extensive experiments
on 5 LLMs across 3 closed-book QA datasets (SQuAD, TriviaQA, and HotpotQA). We
show that factual robustness varies significantly -- smaller models report an
FRS of $0.76$, larger ones $0.93$ -- with accuracy degrading by ~$60\%$ under
increased uncertainty. These insights demonstrate how entropy and temperature
scaling impact factual accuracy, and lay a foundation for developing more
robust knowledge retention and retrieval in future models.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a new metric, the Factual Robustness Score (FRS), to measure the stability of factual knowledge in LLMs.
AI.motivation: The robustness of factual knowledge in LLMs is crucial for reliable applications like question answering, necessitating new evaluation methods that go beyond performance-based metrics.
AI.method: The authors introduce the Factual Robustness Score (FRS), which assesses stability against decoding perturbations by analyzing token distribution entropy and temperature scaling sensitivity.
AI.result: Experiments on five LLMs show that factual robustness differs significantly between model sizes, with smaller models achieving an FRS of 0.76 and larger models 0.93, alongside a 60% accuracy degradation under greater uncertainty.
AI.conclusion: The findings illustrate the significant impact of entropy and temperature scaling on factual accuracy and pave the way for the development of more robust knowledge retention in future models.
key_contributions: Introduction of the Factual Robustness Score (FRS) metric.
Detailed analysis of token distribution entropy and temperature scaling sensitivity.
Validation of FRS across multiple LLMs and datasets.

title: LLMs that Understand Processes: Instruction-tuning for Semantics-Aware Process Mining
comment: Accepted at IEEE ICPM 2025, 8 pages, 2 figures
summary:
Process mining is increasingly using textual information associated with
events to tackle tasks such as anomaly detection and process discovery. Such
semantics-aware process mining focuses on what behavior should be possible in a
process (i.e., expectations), thus providing an important complement to
traditional, frequency-based techniques that focus on recorded behavior (i.e.,
reality). Large Language Models (LLMs) provide a powerful means for tackling
semantics-aware tasks. However, the best performance is so far achieved through
task-specific fine-tuning, which is computationally intensive and results in
models that can only handle one specific task. To overcome this lack of
generalization, we use this paper to investigate the potential of
instruction-tuning for semantics-aware process mining. The idea of
instruction-tuning here is to expose an LLM to prompt-answer pairs for
different tasks, e.g., anomaly detection and next-activity prediction, making
it more familiar with process mining, thus allowing it to also perform better
at unseen tasks, such as process discovery. Our findings demonstrate a varied
impact of instruction-tuning: while performance considerably improved on
process discovery and prediction tasks, it varies across models on anomaly
detection tasks, highlighting that the selection of tasks for
instruction-tuning is critical to achieving desired outcomes.

AI.tldr: The paper explores the use of instruction-tuning for Large Language Models (LLMs) in semantics-aware process mining, finding beneficial outcomes for various tasks.
AI.motivation: To improve generalization in process mining tasks using LLMs, particularly for semantics-aware applications.
AI.method: The study investigates instruction-tuning by using prompt-answer pairs related to tasks like anomaly detection, next-activity prediction, and process discovery.
AI.result: Instruction-tuning significantly improved performance on tasks like process discovery and prediction, though results varied for anomaly detection depending on the model used.
AI.conclusion: The choice of tasks for instruction-tuning is crucial in achieving effective outcomes, with some models benefiting more than others.
key_contributions: First exploration of instruction-tuning in semantics-aware process mining
Demonstrates improved performance on unseen tasks through LLM adaptation
Highlights the critical nature of task selection for LLM training
AI.limitations: Varied performance across models for certain tasks like anomaly detection.

title: JaParaPat: A Large-Scale Japanese-English Parallel Patent Application Corpus
summary:
We constructed JaParaPat (Japanese-English Parallel Patent Application
Corpus), a bilingual corpus of more than 300 million Japanese-English sentence
pairs from patent applications published in Japan and the United States from
2000 to 2021. We obtained the publication of unexamined patent applications
from the Japan Patent Office (JPO) and the United States Patent and Trademark
Office (USPTO). We also obtained patent family information from the DOCDB, that
is a bibliographic database maintained by the European Patent Office (EPO). We
extracted approximately 1.4M Japanese-English document pairs, which are
translations of each other based on the patent families, and extracted about
350M sentence pairs from the document pairs using a translation-based sentence
alignment method whose initial translation model is bootstrapped from a
dictionary-based sentence alignment method. We experimentally improved the
accuracy of the patent translations by 20 bleu points by adding more than 300M
sentence pairs obtained from patent applications to 22M sentence pairs obtained
from the web.

AI.tldr: Development of the JaParaPat corpus which includes over 300 million bilingual Japanese-English sentence pairs from patent applications, significantly improving translation accuracy.
AI.motivation: To create a high-quality bilingual corpus to support translation and research in patent applications, a field often lacking in substantial bilingual resources.
AI.method: Extraction of approximately 1.4 million document pairs based on patent family information, followed by obtaining 350 million sentence pairs using a translation-based alignment method.
AI.result: The new corpus led to a 20 BLEU point increase in translation accuracy, significantly enhancing the quality of patent translations.
AI.conclusion: JaParaPat serves as a valuable resource for improving machine translation in the patent domain, supporting both academic and commercial applications.
key_contributions: Creation of a large bilingual Japanese-English patent application corpus.
Improvement of machine translation accuracy through extensive sentence pair extraction.
Provision of a resource potentially valuable for HCI-related patent translation tasks.

title: LLMSymGuard: A Symbolic Safety Guardrail Framework Leveraging Interpretable Jailbreak Concepts
summary:
Large Language Models have found success in a variety of applications;
however, their safety remains a matter of concern due to the existence of
various types of jailbreaking methods. Despite significant efforts, alignment
and safety fine-tuning only provide a certain degree of robustness against
jailbreak attacks that covertly mislead LLMs towards the generation of harmful
content. This leaves them prone to a number of vulnerabilities, ranging from
targeted misuse to accidental profiling of users. This work introduces
\textbf{LLMSymGuard}, a novel framework that leverages Sparse Autoencoders
(SAEs) to identify interpretable concepts within LLM internals associated with
different jailbreak themes. By extracting semantically meaningful internal
representations, LLMSymGuard enables building symbolic, logical safety
guardrails -- offering transparent and robust defenses without sacrificing
model capabilities or requiring further fine-tuning. Leveraging advances in
mechanistic interpretability of LLMs, our approach demonstrates that LLMs learn
human-interpretable concepts from jailbreaks, and provides a foundation for
designing more interpretable and logical safeguard measures against attackers.
Code will be released upon publication.

AI.tldr: LLMSymGuard is a new framework that uses Sparse Autoencoders to enhance the safety of Large Language Models against jailbreak attacks by identifying interpretable internal concepts.
AI.motivation: To address vulnerabilities in Large Language Models (LLMs) that lead to harmful output due to jailbreak methods, enhancing their alignment and safety.
AI.method: The paper introduces LLMSymGuard, a framework utilizing Sparse Autoencoders to extract interpretable concepts from LLM internals related to jailbreak themes, building logical safety guardrails.
AI.result: LLMSymGuard provides transparent and robust defenses against jailbreaks without degrading the model's capabilities or requiring further fine-tuning, demonstrating the ability of LLMs to learn human-interpretable concepts.
AI.conclusion: The approach offers a foundation for developing interpretable safeguard measures for LLMs, improving overall safety and alignment while maintaining performance.
key_contributions: Introduction of LLMSymGuard framework for enhancing LLM safety
Use of Sparse Autoencoders for extracting interpretable concepts
Establishment of symbolic safety guardrails without fine-tuning requirements

title: MizanQA: Benchmarking Large Language Models on Moroccan Legal Question Answering
summary:
The rapid advancement of large language models (LLMs) has significantly
propelled progress in natural language processing (NLP). However, their
effectiveness in specialized, low-resource domains-such as Arabic legal
contexts-remains limited. This paper introduces MizanQA (pronounced Mizan,
meaning "scale" in Arabic, a universal symbol of justice), a benchmark designed
to evaluate LLMs on Moroccan legal question answering (QA) tasks, characterised
by rich linguistic and legal complexity. The dataset draws on Modern Standard
Arabic, Islamic Maliki jurisprudence, Moroccan customary law, and French legal
influences. Comprising over 1,700 multiple-choice questions, including
multi-answer formats, MizanQA captures the nuances of authentic legal
reasoning. Benchmarking experiments with multilingual and Arabic-focused LLMs
reveal substantial performance gaps, highlighting the need for tailored
evaluation metrics and culturally grounded, domain-specific LLM development.

AI.tldr: MizanQA is a benchmark for evaluating LLMs in Moroccan legal question answering tasks, addressing challenges in low-resource legal domains.
AI.motivation: To evaluate LLMs' effectiveness in specialized and low-resource domains, particularly Moroccan legal contexts, where existing models struggle.
AI.method: The paper introduces a dataset called MizanQA, which comprises over 1,700 multiple-choice questions based on Modern Standard Arabic and various legal influences, designed for benchmarking LLMs.
AI.result: Benchmarking experiments revealed significant performance gaps in multilingual and Arabic-focused LLMs, emphasizing the importance of specialized evaluation metrics.
AI.conclusion: There is a necessity for culturally grounded, domain-specific LLM development to enhance performance in low-resource contexts like Moroccan law.
key_contributions: Introduction of MizanQA, a benchmark dataset for legal question answering in Moroccan Arabic
Highlighting performance gaps in existing LLMs for specialized legal tasks
Emphasis on the need for tailored evaluation metrics and domain-specific LLMs.

title: The Mediomatix Corpus: Parallel Data for Romansh Idioms via Comparable Schoolbooks
summary:
The five idioms (i.e., varieties) of the Romansh language are largely
standardized and are taught in the schools of the respective communities in
Switzerland. In this paper, we present the first parallel corpus of Romansh
idioms. The corpus is based on 291 schoolbook volumes, which are comparable in
content for the five idioms. We use automatic alignment methods to extract 207k
multi-parallel segments from the books, with more than 2M tokens in total. A
small-scale human evaluation confirms that the segments are highly parallel,
making the dataset suitable for NLP applications such as machine translation
between Romansh idioms. We release the parallel and unaligned versions of the
dataset under a CC-BY-NC-SA license and demonstrate its utility for machine
translation by training and evaluating an LLM on a sample of the dataset.

AI.tldr: Presentation of the first parallel corpus of the Romansh language, suitable for NLP applications such as machine translation.
AI.motivation: To create a robust resource for NLP applications by developing a parallel corpus of the Romansh language idioms.
AI.method: Automatic alignment methods were applied to extract multi-parallel segments from 291 schoolbook volumes, resulting in 207k segments and over 2M tokens.
AI.result: The dataset showed high parallelism verified by human evaluation, making it suitable for machine translation, particularly between different Romansh idioms.
AI.conclusion: The released dataset and its demonstration of utility for LLM training confirm its value for advancing NLP applications in the Romansh language.
key_contributions: First parallel corpus of Romansh idioms
High-quality alignment for machine translation
Availability of the dataset under CC-BY-NC-SA license

title: ChatGPT-generated texts show authorship traits that identify them as non-human
summary:
Large Language Models can emulate different writing styles, ranging from
composing poetry that appears indistinguishable from that of famous poets to
using slang that can convince people that they are chatting with a human
online. While differences in style may not always be visible to the untrained
eye, we can generally distinguish the writing of different people, like a
linguistic fingerprint. This work examines whether a language model can also be
linked to a specific fingerprint. Through stylometric and multidimensional
register analyses, we compare human-authored and model-authored texts from
different registers. We find that the model can successfully adapt its style
depending on whether it is prompted to produce a Wikipedia entry vs. a college
essay, but not in a way that makes it indistinguishable from humans.
Concretely, the model shows more limited variation when producing outputs in
different registers. Our results suggest that the model prefers nouns to verbs,
thus showing a distinct linguistic backbone from humans, who tend to anchor
language in the highly grammaticalized dimensions of tense, aspect, and mood.
It is possible that the more complex domains of grammar reflect a mode of
thought unique to humans, thus acting as a litmus test for Artificial
Intelligence.

AI.tldr: This study investigates how well a language model can mimic different writing styles and whether it can be linked to a specific stylistic fingerprint, finding it can adapt style but not indistinguishably from human writers.
AI.motivation: To determine if large language models can be associated with specific writing styles, analogous to human writing fingerprints, through stylometric analysis.
AI.method: Comparative analysis of human-authored versus model-authored texts across different writing registers using stylometric and multidimensional register analyses.
AI.result: The model can adapt its style based on prompts (e.g., Wikipedia entry vs. college essay) but retains a distinct linguistic pattern, preferring nouns over verbs and showing limited variation by register.
AI.conclusion: The findings suggest language models exhibit a linguistic backbone that differs from humans, indicating that complex grammatical domains may reflect uniquely human modes of thought.
key_contributions: Examined the stylistic adaptation of language models across different registers.
Identified distinct preferences in linguistic construction between models and human writers.
Proposed that higher complexity in grammar may serve as a litmus test for AI.
AI.limitations: The model does not achieve indistinguishable writing from humans across different registers and shows constrained style variation.

title: RoMedQA: The First Benchmark for Romanian Medical Question Answering
summary:
Question answering (QA) is an actively studied topic, being a core natural
language processing (NLP) task that needs to be addressed before achieving
Artificial General Intelligence (AGI). However, the lack of QA datasets in
specific domains and languages hinders the development of robust AI models able
to generalize across various domains and languages. To this end, we introduce
RoMedQA, the first Romanian QA benchmark for the medical domain, alongside a
comprehensive evaluation of state-of-the-art large language models (LLMs). We
construct a high-quality and large-scale dataset comprising 102,646 QA pairs
related to cancer patients. The questions regard medical case summaries of
1,011 patients, requiring either keyword extraction or reasoning to be answered
correctly. RoMedQA is the result of a time-consuming manual annotation process
carried out by seven physicians specialized in oncology or radiotherapy, who
spent a total of about 2,100 work hours to generate the QA pairs. We experiment
with four LLMs from distinct families of models on RoMedQA. Each model is
employed in two scenarios, namely one based on zero-shot prompting and one
based on supervised fine-tuning. Our results show that fine-tuned models
significantly outperform their zero-shot counterparts, clearly indicating that
pretrained models fail to generalize on RoMedQA. Our findings demonstrate the
importance of both domain-specific and language-specific fine-tuning for
reliable clinical QA in Romanian. We publicly release our dataset and code at
https://github.com/ana-rogoz/RoMedQA.

AI.tldr: RoMedQA introduces the first Romanian medical QA benchmark with 102,646 QA pairs for cancer patients, highlighting the need for domain-specific fine-tuning of LLMs.
AI.motivation: The development of robust AI models for question answering is hindered by the lack of QA datasets in specific domains and languages.
AI.method: A high-quality dataset named RoMedQA was constructed through a manual annotation process by seven physicians, including evaluation of four LLMs under zero-shot and supervised fine-tuning scenarios.
AI.result: Fine-tuned models significantly outperformed zero-shot models, indicating the necessity of domain-specific and language-specific fine-tuning for effective clinical QA.
AI.conclusion: The study underscores the importance of tailored fine-tuning for improving the performance of LLMs in Romanian medical question answering.
key_contributions: Introduction of RoMedQA benchmark for Romanian medical QA
Construction of a large-scale dataset with 102,646 QA pairs
Demonstration that fine-tuning LLMs significantly improves performance on domain-specific tasks.

title: Cetvel: A Unified Benchmark for Evaluating Language Understanding, Generation and Cultural Capacity of LLMs for Turkish
summary:
We introduce Cetvel, a comprehensive benchmark designed to evaluate large
language models (LLMs) in Turkish. Existing Turkish benchmarks often lack
either task diversity or culturally relevant content, or both. Cetvel addresses
these gaps by combining a broad range of both discriminative and generative
tasks ensuring content that reflects the linguistic and cultural richness of
Turkish language. Cetvel covers 23 tasks grouped into seven categories,
including tasks such as grammatical error correction, machine translation, and
question answering rooted in Turkish history and idiomatic language. We
evaluate 33 open-weight LLMs (up to 70B parameters) covering different model
families and instruction paradigms. Our experiments reveal that Turkish-centric
instruction-tuned models generally underperform relative to multilingual or
general-purpose models (e.g. Llama 3 and Mistral), despite being tailored for
the language. Moreover, we show that tasks such as grammatical error correction
and extractive question answering are particularly discriminative in
differentiating model capabilities. Cetvel offers a comprehensive and
culturally grounded evaluation suite for advancing the development and
assessment of LLMs in Turkish.

AI.tldr: Cetvel is a benchmark for evaluating LLMs in Turkish, addressing task diversity and cultural relevance.
AI.motivation: Existing Turkish benchmarks lack task diversity and culturally relevant content, which Cetvel seeks to improve.
AI.method: Cetvel combines a variety of 23 tasks across seven categories, evaluating 33 open-weight LLMs from different model families.
AI.result: Turkish-specific instruction-tuned models underperform compared to multilingual models; grammatical error correction and extractive question answering effectively differentiate model capabilities.
AI.conclusion: Cetvel serves as a culturally grounded evaluation suite that can advance the assessment of LLMs in Turkish.
key_contributions: Introduction of a diverse and culturally relevant benchmark for Turkish LLMs
Evaluation of 33 LLMs highlighting their performance discrepancies
Identification of key tasks that effectively differentiate model capabilities
AI.limitations: Limited to Turkish language models; not applicable to other languages or broader benchmarks.

title: A Probabilistic Inference Scaling Theory for LLM Self-Correction
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated the capability to refine their
generated answers through self-correction, enabling continuous performance
improvement over multiple rounds. However, the mechanisms underlying how and
why accuracy evolves during this iterative process remain unexplored. To fill
this gap, we propose a probabilistic theory to model the dynamics of accuracy
change and explain the performance improvements observed in multi-round
self-correction. Through mathematical derivation, we establish that the
accuracy after the $t^{th}$ round of self-correction is given by: $Acc_t = Upp
- \alpha^t(Upp - Acc_0),$ where $Acc_0$ denotes the initial accuracy, $Upp$
represents the upper bound of accuracy convergence, and $\alpha$ determines the
rate of convergence. Based on our theory, these parameters can be calculated
and the predicted accuracy curve then can be obtained through only a single
round of self-correction. Extensive experiments across diverse models and
datasets demonstrate that our theoretical predictions align closely with
empirical accuracy curves, validating the effectiveness of the theory. Our work
provides a theoretical foundation for understanding LLM self-correction, thus
paving the way for further explorations.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a probabilistic model for understanding self-correction in Large Language Models (LLMs), illustrating how accuracy evolves over multiple correction rounds.
AI.motivation: To explore the mechanisms behind accuracy changes during multi-round self-correction in Large Language Models (LLMs).
AI.method: A probabilistic theory is derived, modeling the accuracy dynamics and establishing a formula to predict accuracy after iterative self-corrections.
AI.result: The derived accuracy model aligns closely with empirical data from experiments across various models and datasets, validating its effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: This theoretical framework enhances the understanding of LLM self-correction, serving as a basis for future research.
key_contributions: Development of a probabilistic theory for LLM self-correction accuracy dynamics.
Establishment of a predictive formula for accuracy evolution through self-correction.
Validation of theoretical predictions with empirical evidence.
